Well.... I guess I found some interesting ideas from an old and long
topic (Aug 24, 2005): "Introduction---recurrency question".

But any comments on the same issue are welcome!

Cesar

On 6/25/07, Cesar G. Miguel <cesargm@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> Something's been bothering me lately. There are two methods for
> updating the neural network state: asynchronous and synchronous.
>
> These two methods gives different results, so we need to consider them
> when implementing a general neural network class (in NEAT or in a
> general purpose application).
>
> The synchronous mode (or parallel) is just a matrix-vector
> multiplication, where the matrix represents the network weights and
> connectivity and the vector is the state of the network at time t. In
> this mode, all neurons are updated at the same time, only requiring
> information from the last time. You also need to set an initial
> condition (state vector at time t=0), even if the network topology is
> feed-forward.
>
> But if we also update the state vector every time a neuron output is
> computed we have a "real-time" or asynchronous updating. This is
> achieved by choosing a random neuron from the network or following a
> certain pattern (update all neurons going from the input to the output
> like in feed-forward topology). A neuron output is computed using the
> most recent information from the network (not only its last state).
>
> For instance, as far as I could check, Matt Simmerson's NEAT
> implementation (NEAT4J) uses asynchronous updating: from the output
> neuron it recursively updates all the necessary nodes down to the
> input. If there are any recurrent
> links, its first output (initial state) is set to zero or any real
> value you wish.
>
> 1. Since the network's dynamics is affected by these two different
> methods, which one to choose?
> 2. How to choose an initial state vector for recurrent links ensuring
> overall network stability?
>
> I know that the last question is a difficult one since we're working
> with a discrete dynamical system, but what really bothers me is the
> first one.
>
> Just to make things clearer, I have an example where the network's
> input is set to {1} and the initial state is {0,0}:
>
> http://www.ime.usp.br/~cesargm/updating.png
>
> Cesar
>
